Comment: The Reti opening. This forces me to make a different move, as I would normally play e5, but the pawn would instantly be removed.
So I develop my queenside knight, instead. It contests the dark squares in the centre, and woul allow me to double-step my king's pawn, depending on the next move.
He moves his queen's pawn two spaces, so this scuppers my plan. My king's pawn would be captured, and I'd be a pawn down.
So I move up my queen's pawn two spaces. Her bishop has some freedom of the h3-c8 diagonal, but the queen has not as many squares as I would have wanted her to control.
He moves his queen out to plan an assault. He now has more developed pieces.
I decide to attack her with my knight. I might be over-developing here...
...as the queen moves in to attack my king. I have four pieces to block the check here, and one was the right piece...
...but the queen was not one of them. I tried to be too clever here, attacking the queen...
...when it was clearly leaving my knight en prise, and she captures it. I should have blocked with my knight. I didn't realise I could have used it instead of my queen.
I move my free queen up to attack the pawn on c2. That was a bit of a brave move...
...but this was the obvious reply, developing the knight to cover it. I am allowing him do continue his development.
So I bring out my remaining knight to try to help her, and to try to regain some control of the centre...
...and he eyes up my pawn on c7 with his queen...
...so I move it out of the way, also to cover my queen's pawn.
He creates a similar chain by moving his king's pawn one square, to cover his queen's pawn. His light-square bishop now has some freedom, and could launch an attack down the f1-a6 diagonal.
I move up my b-pawn to attack the queen, and to free my bishop form the shorter diagonal...
...forcing her back to eye up my c-pawn from in front. I need to think of a plan to defend it...
...but again I was trying to be too clever, attacking her with my knight...
...when she was obviously going to remove my pawn, and fork my king and rook...
...so I move my king into my queen's starting position to get closer to the bishop...
